frameDefinitions: During a court appearance, a Sentence, generally a punishment, is imposed on the Convict by a Court, usually represented by a judge.
In this frame a Speaker asks an Addressee for something, or to carry out some action.
An Executioner punishes an individual (Executed) with death as a consequence of some action of the Evaluee (the Reason).
A Speaker makes a commitment to an Addressee to carry out some future action.
In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.
frameExamples: The judge <t>sentenced</t> Martha Stewart to 2 years in prison for insider trading.
You <t>promised</t> me you'd come to my graduation.
He was <t>convicted</t> of fraud by Judge Judy.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Convict</fen> is given a <fen>Sentence</fen> by the <fen>Court</fen>.
The <fen>Court</fen> imposes a <fen>Sentence</fen> on a <fen>Convict</fen>.
The <fen>Sentence</fen> is imposed on the <fen>Convict</fen> by the <fen>Court</fen>.
This role denotes the duration of the sentence.
The illegal action of which the <fen>Convict</fen> has been found guilty and for which they are punished.
The Time when the <fen>Convict</fen> is sentenced.
The location of the sentencing <fen>Court</fen>.
The <fen>Speaker</fen>, as in other communication frames, is generally an External Argument.
In this frame the <fen>Addressee</fen> can either occur as an NP Object (usually with a following complement clause) or as a PP Complement of verbs or nouns.
The <fen>Message</fen> is the content of the request that can be expressed as a quote, in a finite or non-finite clausal Complement, an NP Object or PP Complement.

The <fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the <fen>Message</fen>. The <fen>Medium</fen> is frequently expressed as a PP Complement headed by <ment>on</ment> or <ment>in</ment>.
The interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the request.
The <fen>Executioner</fen> is the individual who performs the execution.
The <fen>Executed</fen> is the person who is killed by the <fen>Executioner</fen> in retribution for the crime that the <fen>Executed</fen> was convicted of.
When the execution occurs.
Where the execution takes place.

The Speaker is the person who commits him/herself to do something.  Speaker is usually the External Argument of predicative uses of the target or the Genitive modifier of a noun: <fex name='Speaker'>Jo</fex> made a <t>promise</t> to me. <fex name='Speaker'>Jo</fex> <t>promised</t> me she would cook dinner. <fex name='Speaker'>Jo's</fex> <t>promise</t> to cook dinner came to nothing.

The Speaker's commitment can be made to an Addressee.  With those words which allow this frame element to be expressed, Addressee usually occurs as a PP Complement headed by <ment>to</ment> or the (Indirect) Object of verbs: Kim made a <t>promise</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to me</fex>. Kim <t>promised</t> <fex name='Addressee'>me</fex> that everything would be okay.

An expression of the commitment made by the Speaker expresses the frame element Message.  Message is expressed as a finite or non-finite clausal Complement or an NP Object: I <t>swore</t> <fex name='Message'>that I would never make the same mistake again</fex>. The owner finally <t>consented</t> <fex name='Message'>to sell the business</fex>. They <t>threatened</t> <fex name='Message'>revenge</fex>.
Topic expressions are not very frequent in this frame. They can occur with noun targets. Jo made endless <t>promises</t> <fex name='Topic'>about working harder at school</fex>.

As with other frames in the Communication domain, the <t>Medium</t> of communication may be expressed. Medium is the physical entity or channel used to transmit the Message. Bob <t>threatened</t> the workers <fex name='Medium'>in Spanish</fex>.
The time period during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the commitment.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes the commitment.
The <fen>Judge</fen> (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the <fen>Finding</fen>.
This role identifies the outcome of the <fen>Judge</fen>'s deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This role refers to the <fen>Charges</fen> with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The <fen>Case</fen> on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: Judge Duncan sentenced <fex>Marty</fex> to five years under house detention.
<fex>Judge Duncan</fex> sentenced Marty to five years under house detention.
Judge Duncan sentenced Marty <fex>to five years under house detention</fex>.
Tom will recieve a <t>sentence</t> <fex>of five years</fex>.
A pet store owner was sentenced <fex>for illegaly smuggling protected reptiles</fex>.
He will be sentenced <fex>at a later date</fex>.
Biancaniello will be sentenced <fex>in San Francisco</fex> later this summer.
<fex>The judge</fex> ordered the plaintiff to return the money.
The child implored <fex>her parents</fex> to let her stay up late.
The parents of the missing child made an appeal <fex>on television</fex>.
The truth is, <fex>we</fex> have all put them to death.
<fex>He</fex> was to be hanged in the morning.

The chancellor <fex>yesterday</fex> promised to increase defence spending in real terms next
year.
The july framework has reaffirmed what was promised <fex>at Doha</fex>.
